title: Do cartoon birds have flexible beaks?

body: There are a great many [birds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talking_bird) who can mimic human speech without flexible beaks.  Why would the cartoon variety need them?
body_html: There are a great many birds who can mimic human speech without flexible beaks. Why would the cartoon variety need them?

post.body: Seems like they should if they can speak without problems
post.body_html: Seems like they should if they can speak without problems
post.title: Do cartoon birds have flexible beaks?

body:
Not necessarily, but if cartoon bird beaks could flex like lips, it would make them more capable of reproducing the human vocal range.

Quite a few bird beaks do flex in real life. not the beak it's self as it's made of keratin, but because they have what's known as a Craniofacial hinge.

As for speaking though it's more down to the tongue and voice box being complex enough to produce the sounds that make up words, which is why some birds in the world can mimic words & sounds.

This is why dogs cannot vocalize words quite as well, if at all.
body_html:
Not necessarily, but if cartoon bird beaks could flex like lips, it would make them more capable of reproducing the human vocal range.

Quite a few bird beaks do flex in real life. not the beak it's self as it's made of keratin, but because they have what's known as a Craniofacial hinge.

As for speaking though it's more down to the tongue and voice box being complex enough to produce the sounds that make up words, which is why some birds in the world can mimic words & sounds.

This is why dogs cannot vocalize words quite as well, if at all.
